entry.title: Introducing ‚ÄúPrograms‚Äù in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
When organizations go through large-scale transformations, they often run many projects at once, each with its own goals, teams, and timelines. Keeping track of everything, understanding how these projects connect, and reporting on overall progress can quickly become a challenge.

That‚Äôs why SAP Cloud ALM now introduces a new capability called Programs, designed to make it easier to manage and oversee multiple related projects in one place.

What Is a Program?

Each Program represents a larger transformation initiative, and underneath it, you can have multiple projects that contribute to that initiative. Think of a Program as a big umbrella that brings together several related projects.

A Program gives you one central view to see how all your projects are doing, both individually and together. It helps you stay organized and aligned across teams and regions.

What Has Changed

Previously, when you launched Projects and Setup tile, you accessed everything under a single Projects tab.

Now, that tab has been renamed to ‚ÄúProjects/Programs.‚Äù This reflects the new capability we‚Äôve added, the ability to manage not only individual projects but also Programs, which can bring together multiple related projects under one umbrella.

To access Programs, simply click the small dropdown menu next to ‚ÄúProjects/Programs‚Äù in the navigation area. From there, select Programs, and you‚Äôll be able to view, create, and manage all your programs in one place.

 

Why Programs Are Useful

With the new Programs feature, you can:

  • Group related projects together under one Program.
  • Track overall progress across all projects in that Program.
  • See detailed project information when you need to dig deeper.
  • Run analytics and reports at the Program level to get a complete picture of how your transformation is progressing.

In short, Programs make it easier to see the ‚Äúbig picture‚Äù while still keeping control over the details.

How to Use Programs

Using Programs in SAP Cloud ALM is simple and intuitive:

  • Creating a Program
    • Users with Project Manage authorization can create a new Program.
    • Enter a Title (mandatory) and an optional Description.
    • After saving, the Program appears in the Programs list. 
  • Assigning Projects to a Program
    • When editing a project, you can now assign it to a Program.
    • The Program assignment is optional, each project can belong to zero or one Program.
    • You can also remove a project from a Program at any time.
    • The Program information is visible in both the Project and the Program levels. 
  • Viewing Projects in a Program
    • In the Program Details view, you‚Äôll see a list of all projects assigned to that Program.
    • Projects are displayed with their names, statuses, and timelines(future roadmap), giving you a quick overview of how each project contributes to the overall initiative.
    • Archived projects that are part of the Program will appear as display-only items, they cannot be edited.
    • If a private project is part of the Program but you don‚Äôt have access rights to it, it will be shown as ‚ÄúPrivate Project‚Äù, keeping visibility balanced with access control.
  • API Support
    • You can also manage Programs using the public Projects API available on the SAP API Business Hub:
      • Create or edit Programs
      • Assign or remove a Program from a Project
      • Retrieve single or multiple Programs

 

 

What‚Äôs Coming Next

This is just the beginning. The Programs feature will continue to evolve as part of our roadmap.
In the future, we plan to enhance Programs with:

  • Improved analytics and reporting, so you can track progress more effectively.
  • Grouping of scopes to better organize work within programs.
  • The ability to manage requirements and risks directly at the Program level, and connect them with related projects.

These upcoming improvements will make Programs an even more powerful tool for managing complex transformations.

 

A Real-World Example

Let‚Äôs take a global SAP S/4HANA rollout as an example.

Imagine your company is rolling out S/4HANA across multiple countries Germany, the US, and Singapore, for instance. Each country has its own project to handle local configurations, integrations, and timelines.

By creating a Program for the entire global rollout, you can bring all these projects together under one structure.

  • Each project focuses on the specific work needed in its country.
  • The Program gives you one central place to monitor all of them helping you track overall progress, identify risks, and report on the global transformation effort.

With this approach, you get both clarity and control  you can see how each country is progressing, and at the same time, understand the overall health of your entire global S/4HANA transformation.

 

In Summary

The new Programs capability in SAP Cloud ALM helps you manage large-scale transformations more efficiently. By grouping related projects under one Program, you can gain better visibility, simplify reporting, and coordinate work across your organization.

And with planned enhancements for analytics, scope grouping, and risk and requirement management, Programs will soon become a key part of how you run your most important transformation initiatives.

entry.title: Re: Effortless SAPUI5 Patch Management: Introducing the New SAPUI5 Runtime Repository
entry.content:
Hi @RalphBoehme and @Marian_Zeis,

instead of the generic MIME repository there are now dedicated tables  that are optimized for this purpose.
These are tables with name /UI5/RREP_*. The runtime uses the view /UI5/RT_REPO_V.

The new repository supports having multiple major versions installed permanently. I.e. whenever there is a new major version 2.x, the system will be able to serve 1.x and 2.x in parallel. Please understand that I can't share any timelines regarding this.
It will not be able to have multiple minor versions installed in parallel, since the general strategy of UI5 is to be backward compatible.
To support zero downtime updates, the system can host multiple patch versions temporarily. This allows to apply patches to a system while users are logged on and have the old patch version still running in their browsers.

Best regards
Matthias

entry.title: i acquired asset in 2022 and capitalised on 3st october 2025. now im running unplanned depreciation,
entry.content:
I acquired an asset in march 2022 and capitalized it on October 3, 2025. The asset has a book value of 197,765, and I intend to depreciate it by 95% in November 2025 using unplanned depreciation.

I attempted to post the depreciation using transaction types 640 and 650, but both resulted in the same error (screenshot attached). To address this, I also configured the depreciation key to include a scrap value of 5%, but this did not resolve the issue.

Despite these adjustments, the system continues to reject the posting. I would appreciate guidance on how to correctly execute this unplanned depreciation while ensuring compliance with asset accounting rules.

entry.title: Stop emailing alerts to AIF recipients
entry.content:
I went to /AIF/CUST and inside the path SAP Application Interface Framework -> Error Handling -> Define Namespace-Specific Features.

Maintained recipient under Define Recipients, say 'ZRECIPIENT'.

Configured alert under Configure Alerts, by giving the alert category 'ZALERT' (created in ALRTCATDEF), namespace and default recipient 'ZRECIPIENT'. All the checkboxes are checked for Include Success/Info/Error/Warning/Abort messages.

Then, I went to the path SAP Application Interface Framework -> System Configuration -> Recipients -> Assign Recipients and assigned users and roles.

Now, the users can see the errors/warnings/success count in /AIF/IFMON, which is my desired requirement.

But, the users are also receiving mails. This is not required. We need to stop sending the alert mails to users. How to do it?

entry.title: Re: üì¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
Hi All,
as I see naming conventions not only cover the name of repository objects, but data declarations with DATA keyword and name of local classes in Local Type (includes) etc.

ATC is a post-processing tool, when everything is ready to transport anyway. Getting feedback at that point for me is too late in the process. If a developer starts to do fixes based on ATC checks at that stage, there is a possibility to introduce bugs via rewriting code or the alpha test by developer has to be redone again. This is a very common issue today already.

For me as developer it would be important to get feedback by the compiler during edition about the names of DATA and local classes, and even CDS property names like using Amount postfix and similar described in the VDM Naming conventions etc.
Forex as today it is already in place on BTP ABAP Environment, when defining RAP Cross BOs, the compiler tells you to use the abbreviation keyword in Behavior definition and a shorter name for your for association otherwise it will not work. So the validation happens during edition.

  • I would go creating a new repository object called "NAMC" Naming convention or similar as source code
  • Every new package or software component therefore will have a new property/field: Naming Convention/NAMC
  • It could be assigned on software component or package level
  • If it is not maintained in child package, it will inherit from parent package with dynamic lookup (like when pulling packages with gCTS in ABAP Cloud we have the Transport Layer: $SPL showing the transport layer is inherited from parent)
  • Upon creating structure packages or components, a central Naming Convention variant is defaulted, so this will reduce the maintenance costs to minimum, you deal then with naming conventions when you want to differ from the central rules
  • The persona maintaining such is the development architect/lead developer, and a separate PFCG role is deserved here. 
  • During editon it could be maybe a warning, but upon TR release or ATC check an error

This would be great :), at least an idea to brainstorm or refine in further üòä.

I am really happy with  the lot of initiatives regarding development and tooling by SAP nowadays. I feel supported better and better üëç

entry.title: Re: Update Ariba PR via API?
entry.content:
Hello, 

You can update the PR with a SOAP API !

The documentation is here: Web Service: RequisitionImportPull - Generated by wsdl-viewer.xsl

You need to set the operation to Update, like this : <urn:Operation>Update</urn:Operation>.

Mandatory fields : minOccurs=1.
Optional fields :  minOccurs=0.

I noticed that you can also only update the header (= without the line items).

Alix.

entry.title: pMRP with MTO
entry.content:
Hello everyone,
I‚Äôm facing the following issue and would appreciate your support. I attempted to simulate our next year using pMRP. We particularly need information on how much raw material needs to be procured. Our production is approximately 80% make-to-order (strategy group 20) and 20% make-to-stock (strategy group 10).


I can now use a load file to upload all our materials into the planned independent requirements, but I‚Äôm only able to manage the items from strategy group 10. The Co-Pilot has provided me with the following statements:

This is an interesting question that often arises in SAP environments when trying to include make-to-order (MTO) materials in planned independent requirements (PIR) planning to visualize planned capacity and material consumption‚Äîeven though no specific customer order exists.

Here are the key approaches:

‚úÖ 1. Basic Issue
‚Ä¢ For MTO materials, PIRs are typically not created, as requirements arise based on customer orders.
‚Ä¢ For capacity planning and material consumption simulation, the basis is missing if no order exists.

‚úÖ 2. Solution Approaches
Option A: Create Dummy PIRs
‚Ä¢ For MTO materials, PIRs (MD61) can be created with a special indicator (e.g., ‚ÄúSimulation‚Äù).
‚Ä¢ These requirements are considered in capacity planning (CM01/CM21) and material consumption.
‚Ä¢ Important: These requirements must not flow into actual procurement ‚Üí control via planning strategy or indicator ‚ÄúFor simulation only‚Äù.

Option B: Use Planning Strategy 50 (Make-to-Order with Planning)
‚Ä¢ Strategy group 50 allows PIRs to be created, which are later consumed by customer orders.
‚Ä¢ Advantage: Capacity planning works, and once an order arrives, the planned requirement is reduced.
‚Ä¢ Prerequisite: Material master data must be configured accordingly (MRP, strategy group, consumption indicator).

Option C: Simulated Customer Orders
‚Ä¢ Some companies create dummy customer orders to block capacity.
‚Ä¢ Disadvantage: Complex and not clean for planning purposes.

‚úÖ 3. Display of Planned Capacity and Material Consumption
‚Ä¢ In capacity planning (e.g., CM01), PIRs are converted into planned orders (via MRP run).
‚Ä¢ Material consumption is calculated via the BOM of the planned orders.
‚Ä¢ Prerequisite: MRP run must convert PIRs into planned orders.

‚úÖ Recommended Approach
‚Ä¢ For regularly occurring MTO materials, use strategy group 50.
‚Ä¢ For purely simulation purposes: dummy PIRs with indicators and possibly a separate planning area.
‚Ä¢ Ensure these requirements do not trigger actual procurement ‚Üí control via MRP area or custom planning indicators.

 

The simplest option seems to be switching all items from 20 to 50, but I don‚Äôt see this group in our SAP system and I‚Äôm unsure what impact this change would have elsewhere.

 

My question now is: What is the best way to simulate MTO items (strategy group 20)?
In terms of capabilities, my requirement is: In pMRP, MTO requirements should be handled the same way as MTS requirements.

entry.title: Re: Link between SAP B1 Picklist and its target document...
entry.content:
Hi Anand,

there is no direct and 100% correct link between Picklist and Delivery / Invoice. What Felipe mentioned might be correct only and only if a single Sales Order line is picked on a single Picklist (which is not always the case). The only correct way is to check which Picklist is linked to a Sales Order line, and then what is the link of that Sales Order line to a Delivery / Invoice.

There is a possible workaround where you can create a function which would log into a UDT all the Picklists and when they are converted to Delivery / Invoice their respective links (line, quantity), but there is no out-of-the-box solution.

BR,

Matija

entry.title: S/4HANAÁöÑÊãìÂ±ïÊñπÂºèÊ¶ÇÂÜµ‰ªãÁªç

entry.title: Cross delivery handling unit in Advanced shipping and receiving (ASR) in SAP S/4HANA 2025 release
entry.content:
Cross delivery handling unit means a packing box (like carton) containing products from multiple deliveries as shown in below image. Carton P contains product A and B from two deliveries X and Y respectively. Cross delivery handling unit is very effective for small parts, optimization of packing etc. 

 

Cross delivery handling unit is supported in SAP Extended warehouse management (EWM). Capability for cross handling unit for Transportation management ( TM ) and Extended warehouse management (EWM) with Transportation unit (TU) is supported from SAP S/4HANA 2021 release . Refer my blog https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/cross-delivery-handling-unit-in-tm-ewm-integration-in-s-4hana-2021-release/ba-p/13514920.

Advanced shipping & receiving (ASR) is a new solution for integration between Transportation management ( TM ) and Extended warehouse management (EWM) in SAP S/4HANA. ASR eliminates the requirement of Transportation unit (TU) in EWM and LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) or web service communication between TM & EWM. This new ASR solution was introduced in FPS1 of SAP S/4HANA 2020 release and is evolving with S/4HANA releases. Refer my SAP Press book https://www.sap-press.com/introducing-advanced-shipping-and-receiving-asr-in-sap-s4hana_5836/ and blog https://www.linkedin.com/posts/mrinalkroy_ewm-tm-s4hana-activity-6996835047068610560-e3V7?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop&rcm=ACoAAACqeFcBFLp4MZaIFhaLzuKFWx73dXzaU2U for more details on ASR.

Cross delivery handling unit is not supported in ASR too from S/4HANA 2025 release. My present blog is to describe the functionality of cross delivery handling unit in ASR .

Two outbound deliveries (80004555 and 80004556) relevant for ASR have been depicted in below image.

 

These deliveries are blocked for warehouse execution as in below image as they are transportation driven (i.e will be blocked till the relevant freight order is set for ‚ÄòReady for warehouse execution‚Äô.  

Freight order 6600000909 is now created with freight units created from those deliveries and then set of ‚ÄòReady for warehouse execution‚Äô . Subsequently EWM outbound deliveries also got released for warehouse execution as depicted in below image.

A handling unit 812345678000001816     is created packing both the items (products) from those deliveries as displayed in below image .

This handling unit then gets displayed as ‚ÄòCross -D HU‚Äô as highlighted in below image for both deliveries.

Both of the EWM outbound deliveries then need to be ‚ÄòSet to ready for shipping‚Äô. 

As these deliveries have a single handling unit , both of the deliveries need to be selected for ‚ÄòSet to ready for shipping‚Äô . otherwise error as in below image appears if a single delivery is chosen.

Handling unit then appears in freight order as in below image.

Handling unit is subsequently loaded to the truck and ‚ÄòPost‚Äô or Goods issue is executed.

One of the pre-requisites for cross handling unit is that the consolidation group needs to be same , otherwise below error appears.

This blog is based on my personal tests , observations , insights in S/4HANA 2025 release. Will appreciate your feedback / comments.

entry.title: The Evolution of Payment Methods in SAP: From CNAB Files to Real-Time Banking APIs
entry.content:
At the SAP Inside Track Curitiba 2025, I had the opportunity to present , together with Leonardo Ferreira ( @LeonardoAF1 ),  how banking interfaces are evolving within the SAP ecosystem, and how innovation is reshaping financial integration for companies.

40 Years of CNAB: The Legacy of File-Based Communication

In Brazil, the CNAB format (Centro Nacional de Automa√ß√£o Banc√°ria) has been the standard for exchanging financial information between companies and banks since the 1980s. Developed by FEBRABAN, it defined how payments, collections, and bank statements should be transmitted through fixed-layout text files (CNAB240, CNAB400).

This approach has been robust and reliable, but it relies on static file structures and frequent manual updates. As business processes evolve and demand more agility, this traditional model is reaching its limits.

From CNAB Reports to Banking APIs

The digital transformation and the introduction of instant payment methods like PIX have driven a new era of integration. Banking APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) now enable real-time communication between SAP and financial institutions, replacing the need for batch file transfers.

Within SAP, this means moving beyond traditional tools such as RFFO reports and the Payment Medium Workbench (DMEE) toward integrations that use the SAP Integration Suite, SAP BTP, and secure mTLS authentication.

Real Projects, Real Impact

At MakeValue, we‚Äôve implemented banking connectivity projects (Automatic PIX) with institutions such as Santander, enabling companies like FGM Dental Group, Unimed Porto Alegre, and Magnum Tires to process real-time PIX transactions 24/7 directly from SAP.

These innovations aim to:

  1. Automate the billing and collection process

  2. Reduce operational and financial costs

  3. Improve response time for payments and returns

  4. Scale financial operations securely

APIs: The Future of Financial Integration

While CNAB files still coexist with modern systems, APIs represent the future. They offer flexibility, scalability, and instant synchronization across systems ‚Äî transforming processes such as Accounts Payable, Accounts Receivable, and Bank Reconciliation.

Companies adopting SAP S/4HANA and Open Finance strategies should plan a hybrid transition that combines the stability of CNAB with the agility of APIs.

Final Thoughts

As we move into 2025, we celebrate 40 years of CNAB technology ‚Äî and welcome a new generation of real-time banking integration. The future of financial operations in SAP is not about replacing what works, but about evolving toward intelligence, connectivity, and speed.

@LeonardoAF1

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 1 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: How Future Supply Chain Management Works

More and more companies have recognized the critical power of supply chain management for business success ‚Äì without viable supply chains, there are no satisfied customers, no successful product launches, and no stable value creation. Supply chains need to continuously evolve to meet these needs. Today, digital technologies open up numerous opportunities, which you could only dream of a few years ago: more accurate forecasts, fully connected partner networks, and near-autonomous operations.

At the same time, the economic environment is changing at a rapid pace: geopolitical tensions, changing customer needs, and climate change pose additional challenges for companies. In ten years‚Äô time, supply chain management will look different than today ‚Äì more connected, data-driven, and more adaptable than ever before. But what exactly will change, and how can companies prepare for it today? To answer these questions, SAP Business Consulting and K√ºhne Logistics University conducted a comprehensive study last year, the results of which we present in today‚Äôs and the next five issues.

We are building on a previous study in which we analyzed the visions of the future of companies in the middle of the ‚ÄúDigital SC Hypes‚Äù ten years ago. The mood was euphoric: From numerous conversations with supply chain managers, over 120 potential use cases arose ‚Äì from 3D printed Lego stones to the use of social media data in sales forecasting to mini factories, ultra-fast BOM resolution, and last mile drone delivery. Companies were ready to invest and experiment with new technologies. Much was visionary, some sounded like science fiction ‚Äì and yet the digital revolution in supply chains seemed tangibly close.

Our follow-up study shows a significantly changed picture. Pragmatic realism has given way to the great euphoria. Over the last 10 years, many technologies have been introduced slower and to a lesser extent than expected. The reasons for this include underestimated complexity and misconceptions about the performance of digital solutions (e.g. augmented reality, 3D printing or IoT), as well as an often inadequate technological state of development in the companies. Often, immature technologies, talent shortages, and inconsistent data quality slowed down execution.

Of course, there were also some pioneers ‚Äì often from industries with high pressure to innovate ‚Äì who secure an advantage with targeted investments and know-how. Success often correlated with a focus on clearly outlined use cases with rapid return on investment: better delivery reliability, fewer disruptions, quickly tangible value for the user.

This has been further reinforced by the recent years of pandemic, geopolitical tensions and economic weaknesses. Digital solutions for increasing automation, building integrated planning platforms, or tools to improve the customer experience are now only introduced if their value is clearly demonstrated. Successful projects usually start small and are not scaled until they have a proven effect. Lack of data quality, talent shortages, and lack of system integration are some of the biggest hurdles. Consistent data and change management is indispensable.

Between 2015 and 2025, the view of digital technologies has changed significantly: away from technology-driven euphoria, towards a use-oriented deployment. The potential to achieve true competitive advantage with new technologies in supply chain management is enormous. However, many companies are still lagging behind technology leaders today.

As part of our study, several surveys were conducted with a total of approximately 660 supply chain experts to understand today‚Äôs situation and expectations for 2035. In a multitude of in-depth discussions on Plan, Source, Make, Deliver, and People, we identified measures that companies should implement immediately, regardless of the scenario.

There are some exciting insights for the 2035 supply chains. First, the foundation of any successful digital transformation is a significant improvement in data quality. Companies also need appropriate tools to leverage this data and not remain ‚Äúdata-rich but insights poor.‚Äù People will continue to be important in the future, but their roles are changing. When AI takes on most of the operational work, and employees primarily monitor and develop, they are responsible for tasks that they have never practically performed themselves. Value chain silos will disappear, and technology-driven planning enables seamless end-to-end control.

Few innovation leaders like Amazon, Apple or Procter & Gamble will be able to set new standards on their own. Most organizations do not have comparable budgets, skills, or talents. They will make technological leaps, especially if they can use market-based standard solutions and thus participate in developments.

Regardless of the individual level of maturity, it is possible to record: If you want to play at the front in 2035, you must already start implementing ‚Äúno-regret moves‚Äù: for example, establish robust data governance, standardize processes, and introduce employees specifically to AI tools. Companies that lay these foundations today will not only use technologies in 2035, but will use them strategically. Or, to say it with the words of Wayne Gretzky, ‚ÄúGood players skate to the puck. Great players skate to where the puck is going to be.‚Äú

In the second part of the series, we will show in the next issue why supply chain planning is becoming the decisive success factor, what gaps exist here today between ambition and reality, and how companies can prepare for 2035 with data, AI, and agents. In the subsequent expenditures, we will examine the key findings of our research in the areas of purchasing, production, distribution, and employees.

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (K√ºhne Logistics University) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future‚Äù.

entry.title: Cloud BAdI to Influence Sales Document Copy Control
entry.content:
Cloud BAdIs For Sales Document Copy Control

As I explained in blog Sales Document BAdI Overview, there are following Cloud BAdIs defined to provide more flexibility of control the copying process from a reference document to a sales document. 

  • Copying Requirements for Sales Documents (from Sales Documents) - SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLS 
  • Copying Requirements for Sales Document Items (from Sales Documents) - SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_ITEM_SLS 
  • Copying Requirements for Sales Documents (from Billing Documents) - SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_BIL
  • Copying Requirements for Sales Document Items (from Billing Documents) - SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_ITEM_BIL
  • Data Transfer for Sales Document Headers - SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD
  • Data Transfer for Sales Document Items - SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_ITEM

These BAdI implementations can be assigned into sales document copy control  SSCUIs as special routines, similar to what could be done in VOFM transactions in SAP ECC era. 

According to BAdI definition, these BAdIs support "multiple implementation". It means you can create multiple BAdI implementations and then assign them into different copy control scenarios. 

Normally, the "COPY_RQMT" BAdIs are used to check whether the reference document can be copied to a target document. When business criteria is not met via BAdI implementation, the copy process will be cancelled. The "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdIs are processed after the "COPY_RQMT" BAdI is passed. In "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdI implementation, it is possible to control the field mapping between source document and the target document. 

BAdI Parameters

There are following typical parameters in "COPY_RQMT" BAdIs:

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
SALESDOCUMENTSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data that customer can use to decide if copy control is relevant
SALESDOCUMENTITEMSales document itemImportingContains sales document item data that customer can use to decide if copy control is relevant
MESSAGESMessages Changing Customer can raise messages when applicable 
SALESDOCUMENT_COPYCANCELCancel header copy controlChangingThis is the control field that customer can decide whether to cancel the copy process

There are following typical parameters in "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdIs:

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
SALESDOCUMENT_INSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data that customer can use to decide if copy control is relevant
SALESDOCUMENTITEM_INSales document itemImportingContains sales document item data that customer can use to decide if copy control is relevant
MESSAGESMessages Changing Customer can raise messages when applicable 
SALESDOCUMENT_OUTSales document changeable fieldsChangingThis structure contains all changeable fields on sales document header level that could be copied to the target document
SALESDOCUMENTITEM_OUTSales document item changeable fieldsChanginghis structure contains all changeable fields on sales document item level that could be copied to the target document

Not all standard fields in sales document header and sales document item are changeable in "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdIs. Until release CE2602, following sales document header fields are changeable in BAdI SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD:

  • Purchase Order By Customer
  • Customer Purchase Order Date
  • Shipping Condition
  • SD Document Reason
  • Customer Purchase Order Type
  • Correspondence External Reference 

Following sales document item fields are changeable in BAdI SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_ITEM:

  • Purchase Order By Customer 
  • Sales Product Hierarchy Node Origin
  • Delivery Date Quantity is Fixed
  • Customer Purchase Order Type
  • Correspondence External Reference

The custom fields on sales document header and item level are also changeable fields in "DATA_TRANSFER" BAdIs. 

Business Example 

Supplier company XYZ always negotiates with buyers via sales quotation. Once sales quotation is approved, sales orders can be created by referring to a sales quotation. Company XYZ doesn't want to create sales orders from a sales quotation if the sales quotation is close to expiration, e.g. a sales quotation will be expired in 3 days. 

The supply company XYZ has a special sales process called "Export Order". The "Export Order" is always created by reference to a sales quotation. The supply company XYZ wants to utilize the standard field "Customer Purchase Order Type" to differentiate the "Export Order" from the normal sales orders. 

Solution via Extensibility

The copy control BAdIs can be used to fulfill above requirements from supply company XYZ. The BAdI SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLS shall be implemented to check if the sales quotation is expired in 3 days and stop the copying process. The BAdI SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD shall be implemented to set the "Customer Purchase Order Type" when a sales order is created from a sales quotation. 

Implement BAdI to Cancel Copy When Sales Quotation is Expired Soon

Go to app "Custom Logic" to create a new BAdI implementation for BAdI "SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLS".

Adding the filter "ENHANCEMENT_ID = QUOTE" as this BAdI allows multiple implementations. The enhancement ID can be used to identify the BAdI to be used in certain copy control entries. 

Create the BAdI implementation, and then define the custom logic.

* This BAdI checks the quotation validity period aginst to current order creation date.
* If the sales quotation is closed to experiation date, e.g. expire within 3 days,
* The sales order creation from sales quotation shall be stopped.
    if salesdocument-sddocumentcategory = 'B' and salesdocument-SALESORGANIZATION = '1710'.
        select * into table @DATA(lt_header) from i_salesquotation where salesquotation = @salesdocument-salesdocument.
        read table lt_header into data(ls_header) index 1.
        if sy-subrc = 0.
            salesdocument_copycancel = abap_false.
            data(ls_date) = cl_abap_context_info=>get_system_date( ). "get current date
            "make sure the sales quotation is still valid on current date.
            if ls_date >= ls_header-BindingPeriodValidityStartDate and ls_date <= ls_header-BindingPeriodValidityEndDate.
                data(ls_offset) = ls_header-BindingPeriodValidityEndDate - ls_date.
                if ls_offset < 3.
                    salesdocument_copycancel = abap_true.
                    "raise error message
                    data ls_msg like line of messages.
                    ls_msg-messagetype = 'E'.
                    ls_msg-messagetext = 'The sales quotation will be expired in ' && ls_offset && ' days, copied is not possible.'.
                    append ls_msg to messages.
                endif.
            else.
                salesdocument_copycancel = abap_true.
            endif.
        endif.
    endif.

Save and publish the BAdI logic. 

Open the app "Manage Your Solution" and open the SSCUI 103089 to define copy control routines. 

Create a new enhancement routine for BAdI "SD_SLS_COPY_RQMT_HEAD_SLS".

Go to detail node to assign enhancement ID.

Save the configuration. 

Go to SSCUI 102905 to assign this routine into copy control setting from sales quotation to sales order.

Assign the copy control requirement routine.

Test the behavior of creating sales orders from the sales quotation which is going to be expired in 3 days. 

There is a sales quotation valid from Nov 1st to Nov 12th. 

 

Create a sales order with reference to this sales quotation. 

After press button "Continue", error message is raised based on BAdI implementation logic. 

The copy control requirement BAdI can be used to stop copying process when certain business rules are not met. 

Implement BAdI to Determine Purchase Order Type in Sales Order

In order to fulfill the requirement to determine purchase order type when sales orders are created from a sales quotation, the BAdI "SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD" can be implemented to set purchase order type. 

Firstly, go to SSCUI 103394 to define new purchase order type for "Export Order".

Define a new purchase order type "EXPO" for "Export Order".

Save the entry.

Go to app "Custom Logic" to create a new BAdI implementation for BAdI "SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD".

In the BAdI implementation, add following custom logic to set customer purchase order type.

*   This method can be used to enhance the SAP standard copy control
*   from sales document to sales document and from billing document to sales document.

*   First of all assign existing field values to output parameter:
    move-corresponding salesdocument_in to salesdocument_out.

    if salesdocument_in-referencesddocumentcategory = 'B'.
        salesdocument_out-customerpurchaseordertype = 'EXPO'.
    endif.

Publish the BAdI implementation. 

Go to SSCUI 103089 to define new routine for above copy control BAdI implementation.

In the detail node, assign enhancement ID to this routine.

Then go to SSCUI 102905 to assign this routine 3000093 to the copy control entry. 

Save the configuration. 

There is a sales quotation which is valid until end of 2025.

Create a sales order with reference to this sales quotation.

After click "Continue" button, system navigates to the sales order creation page.

The purchase order type "EXPO" is defaulted based on custom logic in BAdI implementation. 

Moving Forward

The copy control BAdIs provide flexibility to influence sales document copying processes. They can control whether creating from reference is relevant or how fields are mapped from the source document to the target document.

However, not all sales document data is exposed as parameter in those BAdIs, and not all standard fields are changeable during the copying process. We will continue to invest in this direction to bring more flexibility to the copying process.

On the other hand, we also expect customers can raise requirement if any field is missing during copying. Please feel free to submit your requirement through the Customer Influence Portal, see detail in SAP note 2963059. Stay tuned for new features planned in our roadmap.

Hi,

I would like to ask one question, if this is still possible here... You describe the way how to deliver the events from 
SAP to consumers, but the standard SAP Event contain just an Object ID and time to time few other attributes which describe the event. Definitely not enough to replicate the Data to consumer, for example the Business Partner contains just the SAP ID.... You usually need to call an API to read other attributes from SAP and my question is, is there some best practice, where, how to get the rest of the attributes the consumers are interested in?

Should each and every consumer call the API, or should we just call it once and push this JSON to Event Mesh? Clearly if each an every consumer will have own credentials, we could even control which data he could access, and which not... But from other side, we will have as many API calls on the back-end, as many consumers we are sending data to...

BR,

Milan

entry.title: SAP Document AI accelerates document-centric business processes with Generative AI
entry.content:
Authors: @amagnani37 & @merza 

Thank you to everyone who joined our recent partner webinar, "Streamline document processing with SAP Document AI". This session was part of our ongoing partner webinar series, "Talk to your business with Generative AI", and the turnout and engagement were fantastic.

For those who couldn't make it, or for anyone who wants a recap, we‚ÄîMerza Klaghstan, Alice Magnani, and Jacob Tan from the BTP & AI Solution Architects team ‚Äîwanted to share the key takeaways, demos, and technical insights from the session.

Our goal was to go beyond a simple feature list and show you how SAP Document AI can be the centerpiece of a complete, end-to-end business solution.

Here‚Äôs what we covered.

Part 1: What is SAP Document AI and Why Does it Matter?

We kicked off by tackling the core business problem: a staggering 70-80% of all enterprise information is unstructured. Manually processing this data from documents, emails, and scans is not only slow but also expensive and prone to errors.

SAP Document AI, formerly known as Document Information Extraction (DOX), is SAP's AI-powered solution on the Business Technology Platform (BTP) designed to solve this. It goes far beyond simple Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to extract, classify, and validate data with high precision.

Key Capabilities

We highlighted several key features:

  • Multiple Editions: The service is available in Base AI, Premium AI (which includes Generative AI capabilities), and Embedded editions to fit different use cases. We also want to highlight for our SAP Partners that the Premium AI edition is part of the Test, Demo, and Development (TDD) license, which provides a much more convenient model for your non-productive and internal development purposes.

     

  • The New "Workspace" UI: We compared the classic "Basic" UI with the new, full-featured "Workspace," which is the future of the service and includes capabilities like email channel configuration and workflow management.

    It's the new, full-featured environment for all document processing tasks . We want to emphasize that from now on, all the latest SAP Document AI features will be available in the Workspace UI only, so we strongly advise using it for all new projects.

     

  • Pre-Configured & Custom Content (Schemas): The service provides many pre-trained models (called "Schemas") for standard documents like invoices and purchase orders. The real power, however, comes from creating custom schemas for any document type your business needs‚Äîfrom specialized licenses to internal forms.

     

  • Generative AI & Instant Learning: For custom schemas, SAP Document AI leverages Generative AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) to understand and extract information. We also demonstrated "Instant Learning," where the model learns from your manual corrections immediately. After one correction, it knows how to handle that document layout correctly the next time.

    In our demo, we showed how the model initially struggled with a name containing a middle name and extracted the wrong federation name (full name vs. acronym) . After one manual correction and confirmation, it learned immediately. Technically, this feature uses few-shots prompting to make the underlying LLM aware of your previously reviewed documents to improve accuracy on the next run.

Part 2: A Real-World Use Case: "Vertigo Travels"

To make this real, we introduced "Vertigo Travels," a fictional travel agency specializing in sports and adventure holidays. Their key challenge is managing the various kind of documents required for subscriptions, such as ID cards, medical certificates, and diving licenses.

The solution architecture includes:

  1. The Vertigo Travels website, a frontend application,  deployed in Cloud Foundry, serving as entry point for Travelers to select travel packages and upload the necessary documents, such as ID cards or medical certificates. The backend logic is a CAP (Node.js) application also deployed in a cloud Foundry.

  2. SAP Document AI, for all document intelligence operations, communicating via API with our backend application.

  3. SAP HANA Cloud, as a persistence layer for our application, to store all the entities involved in the subscription process.

  4. SAP Build Work Zone standard edition, as the entry point for Vertigo Travels employees to supervise the process. From Work Zone, business users can access the Vertigo Travel website for admin operations, or the SAP Document AI workspace, for instance to review documents. SAP Build Work Zone also allows business users to use SAP Document AI via mobile.

  5. SAP Build Process Automation, to define business rules to automate some document validation checks. Although this could also be implemented as part of the  Vertigo Travels backend application, SAP Build Process Automation enables citizen developers to modify easily the business logics when required.

  6. SAP S/4HANA Cloud, as the core SAP Cloud solution. The Vertigo Travels backend is integrated with modules such as Business Partners, Products, Sales Orders/Invoice, Customer Return for refund.

For the source code, you may refer here for reference.

P.S. if you're planning to work on this prototype, please give us a shout out~! So at least we know somebody is trying our repository out!

We demonstrated three end-to-end scenarios:

  1. The E2E Flow: A traveler, Mary, subscribes on the website and uploads her documents. A back-office employee, Barry, reviews and corrects one document in the Document AI Workspace. Once confirmed, a Sales Order is automatically created in S/4HANA Cloud.

  2. Multi-Channel Ingestion: A traveler, Luca, visits an office. The employee uses SAP Mobile Start to scan his ID and medical certificate. The system then automatically emails Luca about a missing document. He simply replies to the email with his license attached, which is automatically ingested via the Inbound Channel feature.

  3. Automation: A traveler, Claire, uploads an income statement to apply for a discount. SAP Build Process Automation runs a rule to check her eligibility. When she submits her final documents, they have a high confidence score and are auto-confirmed without any manual review.

Part 3: How We Built It (The Technical Deep Dive)

For our developer community, we walked through the "how-to" for the key components.

For the source code, you may refer here for reference.

P.S. if you're planning to work on this prototype, please give us a shout out~! So at least we know somebody is trying our repository out!

1. Setup and Schema Management: We started with the BTP setup, which involves managing entitlements, creating the service instance, and, critically, establishing trust with SAP Cloud Identity Service (IAS) for user authorization. We then showed how to create the custom schemas that power the application.

When you set up your entitlements, make sure to use the application subscription ending in -ias (Identity Authentication Service), as this is the one that provisions the new Workspace interface.

2. API-Driven Development: Our CAP application's backend communicates directly with Document AI's APIs. We showed code snippets for uploading a file (using the FileService) and processing it against a schema (using the SchemaService).

How to retrieve specific extracted values:
While our demo UI showed a simple text extraction, your application will likely need specific, structured data (like "gross_family_income" or "number_of_kids"). The API makes this straightforward:

    • After processing the document, you get a Document ID.
    • You can use this Document ID to retrieve the Document Version ID.
    • Using the Version ID, you can then query the Entities for that document. 4. Finally, you can retrieve the specific value by using the Entity ID (e.g., the ID for your "number_of_kids" field) .

This is how our automation process, for example, was able to pull only the family income and number of kids to pass to the rules engine.

3. Configuring Email Ingestion: We configured the "Channels" feature to monitor an email inbox. This required registering an app in Microsoft Azure, granting Mail.ReadWrite permissions , and then using the Document AI Workspace to map a specific email folder to our target schema.

4. Enabling SAP Mobile Start: This was a key integration for the in-office scenario. It involved three steps:

    • Adding the Document AI dependency to SAP Build Work Zone within the IAS console.
    • Creating a specific BTP destination (sapdocumentaimobilestartintegration).
    • Configuring the app tile in the Work Zone Site Manager with the correct navigation and visualization parameters (e.g., mobilestart.type = documentAi).

4. Automating Logic with SAP Build Process Automation: To keep our application logic flexible, we externalized our validation rules. We created a process in SAP Build Process Automation with a Decision Table (Rule) to calculate the family discount based on income and number of kids. This process is exposed as an API and triggered by our CAP application.

For the source code, you may refer here for reference.

P.S. if you're planning to work on this prototype, please give us a shout out~! So at least we know somebody is trying our repository out!

Part 4: Conclusion, Best Practices, and What's Next

We concluded with some key advice and a look ahead.

Best Practices & Responsible AI

  • Quality In, Quality Out: The accuracy of extraction heavily depends on the quality of your scans.
  • Human in the Loop: While automation is powerful, always design your processes with a "human in the loop" for validation, especially for critical data.
  • Responsible AI: We reiterated SAP's commitment to AI ethics. External LLM providers are carefully selected and are not permitted to store or retrain their models on customer data. Features like continuous data sharing for model improvement are strictly opt-in and should not be used for sensitive personal data.

Get Started and Look Ahead

We are committed to helping our partners build on this platform. Here are the resources to get you started:

  • SAP Document AI Official Help Page: https://url.sap/imohkv
  • Vertigo Travels GitHub Repository: https://url.sap/pi5vwn (The code for our demo app will be available here!)
  • SAP Community for AI/ML: https://url.sap/ai-ml-grp

The roadmap for SAP Document AI is packed with features, including more pre-built schemas, document workflows, custom LLM prompting, and deeper integration with Joule.

Finally, don't miss SAP TechEd Virtual! Be sure to check out sessions AI821v and AI102v for the latest roadmap and deep-dive innovations from the product team.

Please feel free to leave any questions or feedback in the comments below!

entry.title: Getting Started with IoT in SAP Asset Performance Management
entry.content:
Getting Started with IoT in SAP Asset Performance Management

Introduction

With the latest release 2510 of SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), major features in the context of device connectivity and management were enabled and are available as part of the Early Adopter Care (EAC) program. These features utilize the embedded IoT capabilities powered by Cumulocity.

Only two months after its introduction in version 2506 (see also this blog article describing the initial release), many IoT centric features such as direct integration support for OT (operations technology) protocols like OPC-UA, real-time data ingestions via MQTT and REST, live dashboards, streaming analytics and advanced software- and firmware management of devices are now available to SAP Asset Performance Management customers as part of the EAC program.

To celebrate this milestone, we wanted to share a series of how-to guides with you.

In this guide it will be demonstrated how a device can be easily connected to the embedded IoT Platform (Cumulocity) and allocate their timeseries data to assets in SAP Asset Performance Management. It can be seen as a retrofit case where a smart sensor is added and can be attached and correlated to existing assets.

If you are looking for a more advanced way to connect industrial machines and devices to SAP Asset Performance Management, stay tuned for the next guide where we will leverage OPC-UA. We will also dive into applications for Streaming Analytics, how they work differently than existing APM rules and how to combine the strengths of both analytics engines for best results.

Prerequisites

To follow this guide, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

  • You have access to an SAP Asset Performance Management environment with Embedded IoT platform
  • You have a smartphone (iOS or Android)

Step-by-Step Guide

Download and Install the Cumulocity Sensor App

To get started, first of all we need a smartphone to install the Cumulocity Sensor App. It is available on the following stores:

  • Google Play Store: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.softwareag.cumulocity.iotcloudsensor
  • Apple App Store: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/cumulocity-iot-sensor-app/id1516838930 

Connect the App to Your Tenant

As a next step you can go to your provided Cumulocity Tenant ‚Üí Cockpit App and hit the button "Connect smartphone". A wizard will guide you through the steps to scan a QR code with the app. In the final step of the wizard, you can click on "Open Device" to jump to the dashboard that has been created for your smartphone.‚ÄÉ

 

Review Dashboard

In the default dashboard created for your smartphone, you can already see a Iot of useful things including:

  • The location of your device
  • Acceleration sensor values
  • Luxometer of your camera
  • Signal Strength and many more
 

‚ÄÉ

Creating Indicators in SAP Asset Performance Management

With the data in Cumulocity you can now focus on assigning it to technical objects in SAP Asset Performance Management. In our case, we assume that the phone is attached to a "Cooling Water Circulation Pump" but you can assign it to any other asset of your choice. The acceleration sensor is used to detect vibration, similar to a retrofit sensor with a separate mobile uplink.

As a next step, we need to create indicators that represent our acceleration measurements. Follow the SAP documentation to create indicators for your selected asset.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP APM/8c95dca44fda4d56a17f6494f421758d/0b68eeb8daab49b2ac042ae90955e51f.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

Finally, copy the ID of the technical object you want to use for the further steps. It's displayed under the name of the asset in the top left corner.

Assign Data Points to Indicators

Navigate to the Embedded IoT platform, via the "Manage Devices" tile on the SAP Asset Performance Management Launchpad. Within the platform, switch to the "Digital Twin Manager" application via the top right application picker.

Since assets in SAP Asset Performance Management are automatically synced with the Embedded IoT platform, we can search in the Digital Twin Manager for the technical object ID you have copied in the last step to find the corresponding asset in Digital Twin Manager.

Select the asset and navigate to the "Data points" tab. Here you see all indicators as data points. Click on "Link source" and select the data point of your smartphone and demonstrate it on the screen below. Repeat the steps for the two other data points.

‚ÄÉ

After successful assignment, the measurement data will be made available within SAP Asset Performance Management.

Review data in SAP Asset Performance Management

Back in SAP Asset Performance Management, we can navigate to our selected technical object and check if data is already available.

To view the indicators in SAP Asset Performance Management, select them for monitoring like demonstrated below.

Great, you have the data of your retrofit sensor successfully assigned to your technical object and can leverage SAP Asset Performance Management to use it for further use cases.

Conclusion & Next Steps

This guide demonstrated how you can quickly integrate a device to Embedded IoT powered by Cumulocity and assign its measurement data to an existing technical object in SAP Asset Performance Management.

In the next guide, we will use OPC-UA to integrate an industrial device to Cumulocity with multiple data points and assign it to an asset.

entry.title: Re: Automatic bank statement import for Japanese banks in...
entry.content:
Good day @byd 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult Processing Bank Statements for further details.

Here is a summary to your various questions:

Answer to question 1:

Automatic inbound import is not an out of the box solution in public cloud. The recommendation is a Multi-Bank Connectivity solution. See Overview on Automatic Bank Statement Processing and similar question for more information.

Without MBC, you can manually or programmatically use the Fiori apps/APIs to import files. Manage Bank Statements provides more insight.

To summarise, for true automation, I suggest you use SAP MBC or a partner channel that can push files to MBC or your middleware. Otherwise, use the Japan import apps or Manage Incoming Payment Files with a file feed that you trigger. See Integration with SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity for more details.

Answer to question 2:

Regarding Connectivity and formats for Japan, public cloud provides specific import apps that support ZENGINGKYO formats and Zengin XML. See more at KBA 3539536. SWIFT MT940/ISO 20022 camt.052/053/054 is fully supported as electronic bank statement formats in public cloud. You can achieve SFTP/host-to-host through MBC or through your middleware.

Answer to question 3:

You can activate J77, 1EG and 4X8 and use the Manage Incoming Payments Files or Manage Bank Statements apps to set it up.

 

Regarding your 4th. quetion, based on my experience there has been multiple successful implementation cases.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: EWM: How to configure free choice of Handling Unit?
entry.content:
Hi, 

Within our warehouse, we're using an overflow area. The overflow area is used only when the storage capacity for our regular bulk storage has reached its limits. The overflow area is a general storage area.

At the moment, the system suggests a handling unit, upon which our logistics employees have to search for the specific handling unit within overflow. However, sometimes this process is very time consuming as the employee not only has to look for the specific handling unit, but also has to move different handling units to reach the desired handling unit.

In SPRO, we have configured the following:

According to Performance Assistance, we've set 'Level of Avail. Qty. to '1'.

Our config. for Putaway Control

Our config. for Stock Removal Control, Goods Movement Control & Replenishment

We have tested this setting multiple times, but unfortunately, the system does not allow the employee to scan a desired handling unit. It either suggests a handling unit or it completely removes the HU-field in RFUI.

We want our employees to have a free choice in scanning the desired handling unit. So, the system should not suggest a handling unit. How do we configure this?

entry.title: Automatic Replenishment of remaining capacities
entry.content:
Hello all,

could someone help me with the automatic replenishment of remaining capacities for a workday in the tabular planning board in SAP ERP 6.0?

Example: The remaining capacity according to transaction cm50 of capacity type 001 (machine) of some machine on day A is 2 hours, also 2 hours on day B, and 6 hours on day C.

Let's assume that MRP generates a capacity requirement of 12 hours on day D, and the capacity on day D is 20 hours.

Now the challenge: How can I automatically ensure that when SAP draws on the 12-hour capacity requirement of a planned order (created from MRP) on day D, it first uses the remaining capacity from days A, B, and C (i.e., 10 hours total) before drawing the remaining 2 hours from the 20 hours on day D?

Which settings in the strategy profile, workplace, etc., ensure that capacity is always automatically replenished to 100% utilization of a given capacity type?

 

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Issue with BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_TT / CREATE_HDR ‚Äì Confirmation Saved but Not Visible in CO15
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I‚Äôm working on a .NET solution using the SAP .NET Connector (NCo) to confirm and update production orders and their operation quantities (yield, scrap, and rework).

I‚Äôm using the following BAPIs:

  • BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_TT

  • BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_HDR

I‚Äôm updating the TIMETICKETS table for BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_TT and the ATHDRLEVELS table for BAPI_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_HDR, setting all relevant field values.

When I execute these BAPIs, I receive a success message:
"Confirmation of order [OrderId] saved."

However, when I check transaction CO15, the confirmation is created, but the values are not the same as those I passed to the BAPI functions. Only the yield is recorded, and it reflects the total planned output quantity of the production order, rather than the specific quantities (yield, scrap, rework) that I provided during execution.

I‚Äôm committing the transaction using:

BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT
f.SetValue("WAIT", "X");
f.Invoke(dest);

(dest is an RfcDestination)

I get the same result when testing these functions in transaction SE37.

What am I missing or doing wrong?

Thanks for your help!

entry.title: Re: How To get compliant with iFlow Design Guidelines - D...
entry.content:
Hello Chris,

Please fix "copy&paste" error in your script: replace the first occurrence of "sSapAuthenticatedUserName" with "sEquiID" and the second one with "sOrderID".

Then set the following header variables: SAP_ApplicationID, SAP_Sender, SAP_Receiver and SAP_MessageType. You can use Content Modifier - the Message Header tab.

Best regards,

Andrzej

entry.title: Re: A New Paradigm for Enterprise AI: In-Context Learning for Relational Data
entry.content:
Hi @MKreitlein,

Great question - and you‚Äôre right, SAP Analytics Cloud already offers strong predictive capabilities for structured data and defined use cases.

What‚Äôs new with SAP-RPT-1 is the paradigm: instead of building separate models for each task, a single pre-trained model can adapt to many use cases through in-context learning - without retraining or scenario setup. It opens up new ways to apply AI across business data at scale, and there‚Äôs more to come as we continue expanding on SAP-RPT-1‚Äôs potential. We envision the model to play a key role for other SAP products and technologies. Stay tuned for updates down the line.


Best, Markus
